dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (re: prisoners) Release these men at once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Colonel did more than any man could have hoped. If anyone is to blame it's-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: am the officer in charge. I am the man responsible. No one else. Olbricht is moved and rightly so. Meanwhile:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Field Marshal Witzleben is right. I
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I'm going home to await my inevitable arrest. Witzleben turns, marching out. The room remains ill at ease, everyone having just witnessed a serious blow to the Resistance. Those anonymous soldiers present exchange glances of concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He looks at Stauffenberg in a new light now, something darker - no longer the admirer. He shares a look with TWO OTHER OFFICERS. A wordless understanding. He leaves and they follow. 150   INT. WAR MINISTRY - HALLWAY - NIGHT                       150 Herber and company march down the hallway in silence. They stop for Herber to unlock the door to... 151   INT. WAR MINISTRY - MUNITIONS STORAGE ROOM - NIGHT        151 The officers file in, making a beeline for a locker in the corner of the room. Inside are all manner of sub-machine guns, pistols, grenades...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arm yourselves. 152   EXT. WAR MINISTRY - NIGHT                                 152 Under Remer's direction the Deutschland Guard Battalion quickly surrounds the War Ministry. We see a figure moving behind the windows up above... 153   INT. WAR MINISTRY - OLBRICHT'S OFFICE - NIGHT             153 Olbricht helplessly watches troops surround the building below. It is only a matter of time now. He sits at his desk. With a long trembling sigh, he puts pen to paper and writes: "My dearest wife..." A commotion from the anteroom startles Olbricht and he drops the pen. A loud, shrill scream follows. The door bursts open to reveal Herber and his TWO COHORTS. They are supported by A HALF DOZEN ARMED SOLDIERS, all training their weapons on Olbricht. In the anteroom behind the soldiers we see Fraulein Oven quietly slipping out into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 154   INT. WAR MINISTRY - FROMM'S OFFICE - NIGHT                154 Beck, Stauffenberg and Haeften are still making calls and writing orders - doing all they can to keep the coup alive. They are startled when Fraulein Oven bursts in. It is written on her face. 155   INT. WAR MINISTRY - HALLWAY - NIGHT                       155 Stauffenberg and Haeften rush toward Olbricht's office, stopping when they see a MASS OF SOLDIERS surrounding the doorway. A chill runs down our spines when we see Herber talking to none other than Major Remer. Just then, he spots Stauffenberg and Haeften.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Stauffenberg and Haeften turn and run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HALT. BANG. A shot is fired. Stauffenberg and Haeften take cover in a nearby doorway. Haeften returns fire. Stauffenberg clamps his pistol under the stump of his right arm, managing to cock it with the three fingers of his left hand. Awkward. Then he aims and fires. Stauffenberg takes a bullet in the shoulder of his good arm. He drops his gun, bleeding badly. But MORE SOLDIERS appear at the opposite end of the corridor. The loyal Haeften covers Stauffenberg with his body, aiming to fire. But Stauffenberg stops him, shaking his head. It's over. They toss down their guns. Boot-steps approach loudly O.S. As Stauffenberg looks down at the cross and ring around his neck:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colonel Stauffenberg. Stauffenberg turns to find Remer standing there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're under arrest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 160 Stauffenberg, Olbricht, Beck, Mertz and Haeften, the last of the conspiracy, are held at gunpoint. A smug Fromm enters, followed by Herber, the Fat General, Remer and numerous GUN-TOTING OFFICERS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like a pistol, please. Stauffenberg looks at Beck with surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For personal reasons. Fromm thinks about it, then matter-of-factly hands Beck a pistol. Remer quickly steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General, my orders are to deliver the prisoners alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Noted, Major. (to Beck) Get on with it then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, sir-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Continue. The moment is surreal. Beck, seated at the desk, looks at each of his fellow conspirators. A look of thanks, goodbye. With a badly trembling hand he places the gun to his temple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm thinking of earlier times... CLOSE ON: The conspirators turn away, unable to watch. Except Stauffenberg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fromm turns to the other conspirators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: convened by me in the Fuhrer's absence, has pronounced sentence: Colonel Mertz von Quernheim, General Olbricht, Lieutenant Haeften... (glaring at Stauffenberg) And the Colonel, whose name I will not mention, are condemned to death. (to his men) Take them outside. Remer is clearly upset by this. Herber, on the other hand, seems clearer than ever. He nods to his men who drag the conspirators out. Herber personally takes Stauffenberg by the arm. The two men share a look. Nothing needs to be said. Each has found his place. Stauffenberg turns to confront Fromm. He is weak, white from fatigue and loss of blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: trial, make an example of us. This won't win you any favor. And it won't hide you're involvement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Colonel. After a beat, Olbricht turns and leaves. CLOSE ON LIEUTENANT HERBER, tucked away in a corner of the office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Colonel. Stauffenberg is genuinely confused. "For what?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better I die for Germany than for Hitler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WAR MINISTRY - FROMM'S OFFICE - LATER
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you have any last messages, you'd better write them now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My actions speak for me. (to his men) I'd rather my wife and children remember our last time together. The others bravely nod in agreement. But then:
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: FROMM THAT WILL BE ALL, MAJOR

dialogue.raw_text: . Fromm glares at Remer who angrily backs down. Then he turns to Beck and with a casual wave of the hand:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . And as if none of the last minute has even occurred,
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very well then... A court martial,
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Fuhrer will want to put us on
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Involvement. I don't know what you-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You knew and you did nothing. You're just as guilty as we are. Even more so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spare me, Stauffenberg. And those words bring a genuine smile to Stauffenberg's face. He almost pities Fromm now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: No one will be spared. And as Fromm motions for Herber to take Stauffenberg away, we hear music, faintly at first - accompanied by the subtle hiss and crackles of a phonograph... It is the piece Stauffenberg and Nina were dancing to one night long ago... Over this: A voice. A man speaking in German - faint at first, crackling over the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - an attempt has been made on my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nazis take back power, made all the more poignant by the lonely sound of the phonograph, the music slowly rising, growing clearer and eventually becoming score over the silent images of: Conspirators being rounded up and arrested. Among them are faces we recognize... Goerdeler, dragged from a hotel bed by SS OFFICERS as his informing INNKEEPER watches from the doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My comrades. Once again - I don't know how many times it has been now
